page.title: 19WILD LIFE IN WEST BRADFORD
page.content: Ribble Way Footpath allows observation of birds,(various gulls,mallards sand martins,kingfishers,heron),feeding on fish and abundant insect life in the river.High rainfall plus nutrients from grazing animals ensure abundant plant life.Limestone walls are lichen-spotted indicating clean air.Crevices house ivy -leaved toadflax,aspleniums and mosses. Campanulas,butterbur,roses and umbel- lifores common on roadsides.Hawthorn with mixed decid'us trees,holly and ivy form hedgerows between fields and along Eaves Hall and Bolland Lanes.Dutch Elm Disease affected some trees but Elm is still common.Area of mixed woodland, with some exotic conifers present.Rich woodland ground flora under trees along lanes(ferns,dogÂ£s mercury,enchanter's nightshade)-higher up,open pasture species predominate,(yellow vetch,tor- mentil,foxglove).
